natural problem: Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
natural solution: First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.

Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.

To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real^2"
and AB BC AC AX BX CX :: real
and triangle_A :: "real^2 set"
and triangle_B :: "real^2 set"
and triangle_C :: "real^2 set"
and area :: "real^2 set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "AB = dist A B"
and h1 : "BC = dist B C"
and h2 : "AC = dist A C"
and h3 : "AX = dist A X"
and h4 : "BX = dist B X"
and h5 : "CX = dist C X"
and h6 : "AB = 30"
and h7 : "BC = 32"
and h8 : "AC = 34"
and h9 : "triangle_A = {X. dist X I1 = dist A I1}"
and h10 : "triangle_B = {X. dist X I2 = dist A I2}"
and h11 : "\<forall> X. X \<in> line B C \<longrightarrow> area triangle_A \<ge> 126"
and h12 : "\<forall> X. X \<in> line B C \<longrightarrow> area triangle_B \<ge> 126"
shows  "\<forall> X. X \<in> line B C \<longrightarrow> area (convex_hull {A, I1, I2}) = 126"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real^2"
and AB BC AC AX BX CX :: real
and triangle_A :: "real^2 set"
and triangle_B :: "real^2 set"
and triangle_C :: "real^2 set"
and area :: "real^2 set \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "AB = dist A B"
and h1 : "BC = dist B C"
and h2 : "AC = dist A C"
and h3 : "AX = dist A X"
and h4 : "BX = dist B X"
and h5 : "CX = dist C X"
and h6 : "AB = 30"
and h7 : "BC = 32"
and h8 : "AC = 34"
and h9 : "triangle_A = {X. dist X I1 = dist A I1}"
and h10 : "triangle_B = {X. dist X I2 = dist A I2}"
and h11 : "\<forall> X. X \<in> line B C \<longrightarrow> area triangle_A \<ge> 126"
and h12 : "\<forall> X. X \<in> line B C \<longrightarrow> area triangle_B \<ge> 126"
shows  "\<forall> X. X \<in> line B C \<longrightarrow> area (convex_hull {A, I1, I2}) = 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a plane, there are three points A, B, and C forming a triangle with distances AB = 30, BC = 32, and AC = 34. There are two other points I1 and I2, such that I1 is the same distance from all points X in the line BC as it is from A, and I2 is the same distance from all points X in the line BC as it is from A. If for all points X in the line BC, the area of the triangle formed by A, X, and I1 is at least 126, and the area of the triangle formed by A, X, and I2 is at least 126, then for all points X in the line BC, the area of the convex hull of points A, I1, and I2 is exactly 126.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real*real"
and area_ABC :: real
and area_A_I1_I2 :: real
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 \<in> incenter (A, B, X)"
and h5 : "I2 \<in> incenter (A, C, X)"
and h6 : "area_ABC = (\<lambda> (A, B, C). area (A, B, C)) (A, B, C)"
and h7 : "area_A_I1_I2 = (\<lambda> (A, I1, I2). area (A, I1, I2)) (A, I1, I2)"
shows  "area_A_I1_I2 \<ge> 126"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real*real"
and area_ABC :: real
and area_A_I1_I2 :: real
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 \<in> incenter (A, B, X)"
and h5 : "I2 \<in> incenter (A, C, X)"
and h6 : "area_ABC = (\<lambda> (A, B, C). area (A, B, C)) (A, B, C)"
and h7 : "area_A_I1_I2 = (\<lambda> (A, I1, I2). area (A, I1, I2)) (A, I1, I2)"
shows  "area_A_I1_I2 \<ge> 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a triangle $ABC$ with sides $AB = 30$, $BC = 32$, and $AC = 34$, let $X$ be a point in the open segment $BC$. Let $I_1$ and $I_2$ be the incenters of triangles $ABX$ and $ACX$, respectively. Let $area_{ABC}$ denote the area of triangle $ABC$, and $area_{A I_1 I_2}$ denote the area of triangle $AI_1I_2$. Prove that the area of triangle $AI_1I_2$ is greater than or equal to $126$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real^2"
and area :: "(real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> real"
and a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter A B X"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter A C X"
and h6 : "a = dist I1 I2"
and h7 : "b = dist A I1"
and h8 : "c = dist A I2"
and h9 : "\<forall>X. X \<in> open_segment B C \<longrightarrow> area A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
shows  "area A I1 I2 = 126"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real^2"
and area :: "(real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> (real^2) \<Rightarrow> real"
and a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter A B X"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter A C X"
and h6 : "a = dist I1 I2"
and h7 : "b = dist A I1"
and h8 : "c = dist A I2"
and h9 : "\<forall>X. X \<in> open_segment B C \<longrightarrow> area A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
shows  "area A I1 I2 = 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In triangle $ABC$ with sides $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$, let $X$ be an arbitrary point on the open segment $BC$. Let $I_1$ and $I_2$ be the incenters of triangles $ABX$ and $ACX$, respectively. Let $a$ be the distance between $I_1$ and $I_2$, $b$ be the distance between $A$ and $I_1$, and $c$ be the distance between $A$ and $I_2$. If the area of triangle $AI_1I_2$ is at least $126$ for any $X$ on the open segment $BC$, find the value of the area of triangle $AI_1I_2$. The final answer is $126$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "(real, real) geometry"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "incenter A B X = I1"
and h5 : "incenter A C X = I2"
shows  "area_triangle A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "(real, real) geometry"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "incenter A B X = I1"
and h5 : "incenter A C X = I2"
shows  "area_triangle A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a triangle ABC with side lengths AB = 30, BC = 32, and AC = 34, let X be a point on the open segment BC. Let I1 be the incenter of triangle ABX and I2 be the incenter of triangle ACX. What is the minimum area of triangle AI1I2? The final answer is at least 126.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real*real" 
and triangle_area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> {(B + k * (C - B)) | k. 0 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 1}"
and h4 : "I1 \<in> {incenter A B X}"
and h5 : "I2 \<in> {incenter A C X}"
and h6 : "is_minimum (\<lambda>X. triangle_area A I1 I2) X"
shows  "triangle_area A I1 I2 = 126"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real*real" 
and triangle_area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> {(B + k * (C - B)) | k. 0 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 1}"
and h4 : "I1 \<in> {incenter A B X}"
and h5 : "I2 \<in> {incenter A C X}"
and h6 : "is_minimum (\<lambda>X. triangle_area A I1 I2) X"
shows  "triangle_area A I1 I2 = 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a triangle ABC with side lengths AB = 30, BC = 32, and AC = 34, consider a point X on side BC such that X lies between B and C. Let I1 be the incenter of triangle ABX, and I2 be the incenter of triangle ACX. Find the minimum possible area of triangle AI1I2. The final answer is 126.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes triangle_ABC :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area_AI1I2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "triangle_ABC 30 32 34"
and h1 : "\<And>X I1 I2. X \<in> {a. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a \<le> 32} \<Longrightarrow> I1 = incenter (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) (X) \<Longrightarrow> I2 = incenter (triangle_ABC 34 32 30) (X) \<Longrightarrow> area_AI1I2 I1 I2 (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) = (\<lambda> I1 I2. area (triangle I1 I2 (triangle_ABC 30 32 34)))"
shows  "Min {area_AI1I2 I1 I2 (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) | I1 I2 X. X \<in> {a. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a \<le> 32} \<and> I1 = incenter (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) (X) \<and> I2 = incenter (triangle_ABC 34 32 30) (X)} = 126"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes triangle_ABC :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
and area_AI1I2 :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "triangle_ABC 30 32 34"
and h1 : "\<And>X I1 I2. X \<in> {a. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a \<le> 32} \<Longrightarrow> I1 = incenter (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) (X) \<Longrightarrow> I2 = incenter (triangle_ABC 34 32 30) (X) \<Longrightarrow> area_AI1I2 I1 I2 (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) = (\<lambda> I1 I2. area (triangle I1 I2 (triangle_ABC 30 32 34)))"
shows  "Min {area_AI1I2 I1 I2 (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) | I1 I2 X. X \<in> {a. a \<ge> 0 \<and> a \<le> 32} \<and> I1 = incenter (triangle_ABC 30 32 34) (X) \<and> I2 = incenter (triangle_ABC 34 32 30) (X)} = 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In triangle ABC with side lengths 30, 32, and 34, let I1 be the incenter of triangle ABC when X is between 0 and 32 inclusive, and I2 be the incenter of triangle ACB when X is between 0 and 32 inclusive. Find the minimum area of the triangle formed by points A, I1, and I2. The final answer is 126.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "euclidean_distance A B = 30"
and h1 : "euclidean_distance B C = 32"
and h2 : "euclidean_distance A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter (A, B, X)"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter (A, C, X)"
shows  "min_area_triangle A I1 I2 = 126"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126

Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "euclidean_distance A B = 30"
and h1 : "euclidean_distance B C = 32"
and h2 : "euclidean_distance A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter (A, B, X)"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter (A, C, X)"
shows  "min_area_triangle A I1 I2 = 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a triangle with vertices $A$, $B$, and $C$ and side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Let $X$ be a point on the segment $BC$. Let $I_1$ be the incenter of triangle $ABX$, and let $I_2$ be the incenter of triangle $ACX$. What is the minimum possible area of the triangle $AI_1I_2$? The final answer is 126.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real*real"
and area_triangle :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter (A, B, X)"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter (A, C, X)"
shows  "area_triangle A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126

Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real*real"
and area_triangle :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> closed_segment B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter (A, B, X)"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter (A, C, X)"
shows  "area_triangle A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a triangle with vertices A, B, and C, the distance between A and B is 30, the distance between B and C is 32, and the distance between A and C is 34. Let X be a point on the line segment BC. Let I1 be the incenter of triangle ABX and I2 be the incenter of triangle ACX. Find the minimum possible area of triangle AI1I2. The final answer is greater than or equal to 126.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real * real"
and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "incenter A B X I1"
and h5 : "incenter A C X I2"
shows  "area A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126

 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real * real"
and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> open_segment B C"
and h4 : "incenter A B X I1"
and h5 : "incenter A C X I2"
shows  "area A I1 I2 \<ge> 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In triangle $ABC$, $AB = 30$, $BC = 32$, and $AC = 34$. Let $X$ be a point on segment $BC$, and let $I_1$ and $I_2$ be the incenters of triangles $ABX$ and $ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible value of the area of triangle $AI_1I_2$. The final answer is $\geq 126$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real * real"
and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
and incenter :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
and dist :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> line_seg B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter A B X"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter A C X"
shows  "(LEAST a. \<exists> X. X \<in> line_seg B C \<and> area A I1 I2 = a) = 126"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\triangle ABC$ have side lengths $AB=30$, $BC=32$, and $AC=34$. Point $X$ lies in the interior of $\overline{BC}$, and points $I_1$ and $I_2$ are the incenters of $\triangle ABX$ and $\triangle ACX$, respectively. Find the minimum possible area of $\triangle AI_1I_2$ as $X$ varies along $\overline{BC}$.
 The final Answer is 126
 ### Proof
 First note that\[\angle I_1AI_2 = \angle I_1AX + \angle XAI_2 = \frac{\angle BAX}2 + \frac{\angle CAX}2 = \frac{\angle A}2\]is a constant not depending on $X$, so by $[AI_1I_2] = \tfrac12(AI_1)(AI_2)\sin\angle I_1AI_2$ it suffices to minimize $(AI_1)(AI_2)$.
 Let $a = BC$, $b = AC$, $c = AB$, and $\alpha = \angle AXB$. Remark that\[\angle AI_1B = 180^\circ - (\angle I_1AB + \angle I_1BA) = 180^\circ - \tfrac12(180^\circ - \alpha) = 90^\circ + \tfrac\alpha 2.\]Applying the Law of Sines to $\triangle ABI_1$ gives\[\frac{AI_1}{AB} = \frac{\sin\angle ABI_1}{\sin\angle AI_1B}\qquad\Rightarrow\qquad AI_1 = \frac{c\sin\frac B2}{\cos\frac\alpha 2}.\]Analogously one can derive $AI_2 = \tfrac{b\sin\frac C2}{\sin\frac\alpha 2}$, and so\[[AI_1I_2] = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{2\cos\frac\alpha 2\sin\frac\alpha 2} = \frac{bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2}{\sin\alpha}\geq bc\sin\frac A2 \sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2,\]with equality when $\alpha = 90^\circ$, that is, when $X$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{BC}$.
 In this case the desired area is $bc\sin\tfrac A2\sin\tfrac B2\sin\tfrac C2$.
 To make this feasible to compute, note that\[\sin\frac A2=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos A}2}=\sqrt{\frac{1-\frac{b^2+c^2-a^2}{2bc}}2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{(a-b+c)(a+b-c)}{4bc}}.\]Applying similar logic to $\sin \tfrac B2$ and $\sin\tfrac C2$ and simplifying yields a final answer of\begin{align}bc\sin\frac A2\sin\frac B2\sin\frac C2&=bc\cdot\dfrac{(a-b+c)(b-c+a)(c-a+b)}{8abc}\\&=\dfrac{(30-32+34)(32-34+30)(34-30+32)}{8\cdot 32}=\boxed{126}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C X I1 I2 :: "real * real"
and area :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
and incenter :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real)"
and dist :: "(real * real) \<Rightarrow> (real * real) \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "dist A B = 30"
and h1 : "dist B C = 32"
and h2 : "dist A C = 34"
and h3 : "X \<in> line_seg B C"
and h4 : "I1 = incenter A B X"
and h5 : "I2 = incenter A C X"
shows  "(LEAST a. \<exists> X. X \<in> line_seg B C \<and> area A I1 I2 = a) = 126"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a triangle with sides of length 30, 32, and 34, find the smallest possible area of a triangle formed by a point X on the line segment connecting two vertices of the triangle (B and C) and the incenters of triangles ABX and ACX. The final answer is 126.
